description: The Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines Episcopal Commission on Migrants and Itinerant People on Thursday, June 4, has called on Filipino chaplains abroad to offer masses and prayers for peace and healing in the United States amid the growing protest actions there due to the death of African-American George Floyd.  "Migrante International...
text:
By Leslie Ann Aquino

The Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines Episcopal Commission on
Migrants and Itinerant People on Thursday, June 4, has called on Filipino
chaplains abroad to offer masses and prayers for peace and healing in the
United States amid the growing protest actions there due to the death of
African-American George Floyd.

"We appeal to our Filipino chaplains for the pastoral care of OFWs here and
abroad, land or sea-based, to offer Holy Masses, to pray with their co-
nationals in their chaplaincies for peace, end to violence, and healing in
US," CBCP - ECMI vice chairman Bishop Ruperto Santos said in an interview.

The Balanga, Bataan prelate also appealed to Filipinos there to remain "calm,
caring, and conciliatory."

"Yes, we must speak. (But) let our words bring out healing, not division;
about truth, not to instill fear; inspire helps, not to hurt," said Santos.

"Yes, we stand and make stand. Let it be always on rule of law, for common
good, and promotion of life," he added.

Migrante International, meantime, expressed their solidarity to the millions
of people in the US and around the world who have taken into the streets to
demand justice and equality.

"Migrante International vehemently denounces the brutal murder of George Floyd
by the Minneapolis Police Department," the group said in a statement.

"We extend our support and Filipino migrant communities mourn with the friends
and loved ones of George Floyd who are grief-stricken by his tragic passing,"
Migrante added.

"The violent repression by US authorities of poor, black and migrant
communities in the United States coincides with the imperialist wars of
aggression being waged by the Pentagon in countries whose people are asserting
their right to national liberation and self-determination," the group said.

Migrante said the crimes against humanity have led to the displacement and
forced migration of hundreds of millions of people around the globe including
Filipinos.

"It is time to fight back and get rid of racism and oppression by creating a
democratic society that truly values people's lives and freedom," said the
group.

CAPTION(S):

A large painting depicting the face of George Floyd stands at a memorial site
outside Cup Foods on June 3, 2020 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. (Stephen
Maturen/Getty Images/AFP / MANILA BULLETIN)

title: Groups express solidarity with George Floyd supporters.(National)
html:
By Leslie Ann Aquino

The Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines Episcopal Commission on Migrants and Itinerant People on Thursday, June 4, has called on Filipino chaplains abroad to offer masses and prayers for peace and healing in the United States amid the growing protest actions there due to the death of African-American George Floyd.

"We appeal to our Filipino chaplains for the pastoral care of OFWs here and abroad, land or sea-based, to offer Holy Masses, to pray with their co-nationals in their chaplaincies for peace, end to violence, and healing in US," CBCP - ECMI vice chairman Bishop Ruperto Santos said in an interview.

The Balanga, Bataan prelate also appealed to Filipinos there to remain "calm, caring, and conciliatory."

"Yes, we must speak. (But) let our words bring out healing, not division; about truth, not to instill fear; inspire helps, not to hurt," said Santos.

"Yes, we stand and make stand. Let it be always on rule of law, for common good, and promotion of life," he added.

Migrante International, meantime, expressed their solidarity to the millions of people in the US and around the world who have taken into the streets to demand justice and equality.

"Migrante International vehemently denounces the brutal murder of George Floyd by the Minneapolis Police Department," the group said in a statement.

"We extend our support and Filipino migrant communities mourn with the friends and loved ones of George Floyd who are grief-stricken by his tragic passing," Migrante added.

"The violent repression by US authorities of poor, black and migrant communities in the United States coincides with the imperialist wars of aggression being waged by the Pentagon in countries whose people are asserting their right to national liberation and self-determination," the group said.

Migrante said the crimes against humanity have led to the displacement and forced migration of hundreds of millions of people around the globe including Filipinos.

"It is time to fight back and get rid of racism and oppression by creating a democratic society that truly values people's lives and freedom," said the group.

A large painting depicting the face of George Floyd stands at a memorial site outside Cup Foods on June 3, 2020 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. (Stephen Maturen/Getty Images/AFP / MANILA BULLETIN)
